description: Touro Synagogue, a building of exquisite beauty and design, steeped in history and ideals, and one of the most historically significant Jewish buildings in America, was designated a National Historic Site in 1946. Dedicated in 1763, it still serves an active congregation and each year greets over 30,000 visitors who come to see the magnificent interior and hear its remarkable story.

images.title: Touro Synagogue
images.altText: Front view of Touro Synagogue

images.title: Touro Synagogue Park
images.altText: Image of Touro Synagogue

name: Tule Lake
description: The Tule Lake National Monument includes both the the Tule Lake Segregation Center, the largest and most controversial of the sites where Japanese Americans were incarcerated during World War II, and Camp Tulelake, which was first a Civilian Conservation Corps camp, then an additional facility to detain Japanese Americans, and finally a prisoner of war camp.

images.title: Camp Tulelake Barrack
images.altText: Camp Tulelake Barrack

images.title: Camp Tulelake as a CCC Camp in 1936
images.altText: Camp Tulelake as a CCC Camp in 1936

name: Tule Springs Fossil Beds
fullName: Tule Springs Fossil Beds National Monument
description: Over the last ~570,000 years, water has transformed the Upper Las Vegas Valley. Tule Springs Fossil Beds National Monument is an urban park that preserves the unique story of this ever-changing ecosystem.

images.title: Tule Springs Fossil Beds National Monument
images.altText: Tule Springs during winter

name: Tumacácori
description: Tumacácori sits at a cultural crossroads in the Santa Cruz River valley. Here O’odham, Yaqui, and Apache people met and mingled with European Jesuit and Franciscan missionaries, settlers, and soldiers, sometimes in conflict and sometimes in cooperation. Follow the timeworn paths and discover stories that connect us to enduring relationships, vibrant cultures, and traditions of long ago.

images.title: La Fiesta de Tumacácori
images.altText: folklorico dancers in front of church

images.title: Tumacácori on a Summer Day
images.altText: panorama of mission church with green grass and clouds

name: Tupelo
description: In July, 1864, Union forces, including men from the United States Colored Troops, marched into Tupelo, Mississippi. Disorganized Confederate soldiers fought fiercely but could not overpower the federal troops. Neither side could claim a clear victory, but Union troops had succeeded in their main goal: keeping the Confederates away from Union railroads in Tennessee.

images.title: Tupelo National Battlefield Monument
images.altText: The monument with a cannon

name: Tuskegee Airmen
description: Before the first African American military pilots became known as the "Red Tails" they wore striped tails as they began their flight training in the Army's PT-17 Stearman bi-plane. Their flying adventure started at Moton Field, in Tuskegee, Alabama, where the Army Air Corps conducted a military test to determine if African Americans could be trained to fly combat aircraft.

images.title: And There Were Women...
images.altText: Female Mechanic works on military aircraft

images.title: First Flight - Eleanor Roosevelt was the first First Lady to fly with a Negro Pilot.
images.altText: Small Yellow training plane used in the Civilian Pilot Training Prograj - J3 Piper Cub

name: Tuskegee Institute
description: In 1881, Booker T. Washington arrived in Alabama and started building Tuskegee Institute both in reputation and literally brick by brick. He recruited the best and the brightest to come and teach here including George Washington Carver who arrived in 1896. Carver’s innovations in agriculture, especially with peanuts, expanded Tuskegee’s standing throughout the country. The story continues….

images.title: Carver with Friend and Fellow Inventor, Henry Ford
images.altText: George W. Carver and Henry Ford seated facing one another talking

images.title: Carver's Peanut Oil
images.altText: Bottle of Peanut Oil with green label - one of Dr. Carver's many uses for the peanut

name: Tuzigoot
description: Water flows under and through this landscape, feeding the growth of people and towns. The Verde Valley is watered by snowmelt, summer monsoons, and springs that well up from the ancient sedimentary rocks. In the heart of the valley, a thousand years ago, people began to build a little hilltop pueblo that would grow into one of the largest villages in the area.

images.title: Inside Tuzigoot
images.altText: The inside of a masonry room with wood posts supporting the roof.

images.title: Tuzigoot Pueblo
images.altText: A sunny day at Tuzigoot

name: Ulysses S Grant
fullName: Ulysses S Grant National Historic Site
description: Ulysses S. Grant is known as the victorious Civil War general who saved the Union and the 18th President of the United States. He first met Julia Dent, his future wife, at her family home, named White Haven. From 1854 to 1859 the Dents, Grants and an enslaved African-American workforce lived on the property.

images.title: Museum Exhibits
images.altText: boy looking at touchscreen in museum

images.title: Outbuildings
images.altText: To the left is the ice house and to right is chicken house.

name: Valles Caldera
description: About 1.25 million years ago, a spectacular volcanic eruption created the 13-mile wide circular depression now known as the Valles Caldera. The preserve is known for its huge mountain meadows, abundant wildlife, and meandering streams. The area also preserves the homeland of ancestral native peoples and embraces a rich ranching history.

images.title: Elk Bulls Fighting
images.altText: Two bull elk fighting.

images.title: Fall Color in Valles Caldera
images.altText: Aspen tree trunks with golden fall leaf color above

name: Valley Forge
description: Valley Forge is the encampment site of the Continental Army during the winter of 1777-1778. The park features 3,500 acres of monuments, meadows, and woodlands commemorating the sacrifices and perseverance of the Revolutionary War generation and honoring the power of people to pull together and overcome adversity during extraordinary times.

images.title: Muhlenberg's Brigade at Sunset
images.altText: outdoors, log huts, gravel path, sunset, clouds

images.title: National Memorial Arch
images.altText: outdoors, arch, monument, snow, trees

name: Vanderbilt Mansion
description: Built by of one of the first families of wealth in America. Designed by one of the nation's preeminent architects. The Vanderbilt Mansion is a home built expressly for the aristocratic lifestyle.

images.title: Overlook
images.altText: View of the Hudson River looking North from the Overlook

images.title: Summer Concert Series
images.altText: West Point Band performs at the Vanderbilt Mansion

name: Vicksburg
description: To Confederate President Jefferson Davis, Vicksburg was the "nailhead that holds the South's two halves together." President Abraham Lincoln remarked "Vicksburg is the key" to victory, and could be the north's lifeline into the south. As the federals closed in on the Fortress City, they were met by a ring of forts with over 170 cannon. The resulting battle would determine the war's outcome.

images.title: Illinois State Memorial
images.altText: Stars behind the Illinois State Memorial

images.title: Ranger Programs
images.altText: Park Ranger in Civil War Uniform Talks to Crowd

name: Vietnam Veterans Memorial
description: Honoring the men and women who served in the controversial Vietnam War, the Vietnam Veterans Memorial chronologically lists the names of 58,318 Americans who gave their lives in service to their country.

images.title: Three Servicemen Statue
images.altText: A bronze statue of three soldiers standing together, carrying weapons, and looking to their right.

images.title: Vietnam Veterans Memorial
images.altText: Notes and flags set at the base of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, a black wall inscribed with names.

name: Virgin Islands
description: Go beyond Virgin Islands National Park's stunning white-sand beaches. Hike to historic plantation sites to learn about a challenging past when sugar and enslaved labor dominated life on the island. Visit the Indigenous Taino's ancient petroglyphs. Snorkel coral reefs to discover hidden marine life. Two-thirds of the island of St. John is national park, making it a unique destination for visitors.

images.title: Four Stilts for the Bird Watchers
images.altText: Four Stilts in the Francis Bay Pond

images.title: Queen Angel Fish
images.altText: Queen Angel Fish

name: Virgin Islands Coral Reef
fullName: Virgin Islands Coral Reef National Monument
description: Virgin Islands Coral Reef National Monument includes federal submerged lands within the 3-mile belt off the island of St. John. These waters support a diverse and complex system of coral reefs and other ecosystems such as shoreline mangrove forests and seagrass beds.

images.title: Parrot Fish
images.altText: Parrot Fish posing for the camera over several corals

name: Voyageurs
description: With 218,055 acres, Voyageurs National Park is an adventure wonderland all year long full of exposed rock ridges, cliffs, wetlands, forests, streams and lakes. This is a place of transition between land and aquatic ecosystems, between southern boreal and northern hardwood forests, and between wild and developed areas. Whether you are exploring by land, water or ice there is something for everyone.

images.title: Anderson Bay
images.altText: rock cliffs along the lake

images.title: Fall Colors
images.altText: orange, yellow, and green colors are showing in the fall foliage

name: Waco Mammoth
description: Standing as tall as 14 feet and weighing 20,000 pounds, Columbian mammoths roamed across what is present-day Texas thousands of years ago. Today, the fossil specimens represent the nation's first and only recorded evidence of a nursery herd of ice age Columbian mammoths.

images.title: Entrance Sign to Waco Mammoth
images.altText: Entrance sign to Waco Mammoth with bluebonnets in foreground.

images.title: Interior of Dig Shelter
images.altText: Visitors view fossils from walkway

name: Walnut Canyon
description: Come gaze across curved canyon walls. Among the remarkable geological formations of the canyon itself, the former homes of ancient inhabitants are easily evident. Along the trails you can imagine life within Walnut Canyon, while visiting actual pueblos and walking in the steps of those who came before.

images.title: A Visitor at Walnut Canyon
images.altText: a visitor looks out over Walnut Canyon from the trail

images.title: Cliff Dwellings
images.altText: sunlight illuminates stone walls in a canyon cliff dwelling

name: War In The Pacific
fullName: War In The Pacific National Historical Park
description: War in the Pacific National Historical Park was established to commemorate the bravery and sacrifice of those participating in the campaigns of the Pacific Theater of World War II and to conserve and interpret outstanding natural, scenic, and historic values and objects of the island of Guam.

images.title: Apaca point
images.altText: Calm water beach at sunset.

images.title: Asan Beach Overlook
images.altText: Mountain view down toward beach.

name: Washington Monument
description: Built to honor George Washington, the United States' first president, the 555-foot marble obelisk towers over Washington, D.C.

images.title: Birds eye view
images.altText: Aerial View of the Washington Monument

images.title: Washington Monument
images.altText: The Washington Monument, a white marble obelisk, towers above a ring of US Flags.

name: Washita Battlefield
description: On November 27, 1868, Lt. Colonel George Armstrong Custer led the 7th US Cavalry on a surprise dawn attack on a Cheyenne village led by Peace Chief Black Kettle. The event was an example of the tragic clash of cultures that occurred during the Great Plains Wars. It is also a place of remembrance and reflection for those who died here.

images.title: "Meeting the Enemy"
images.altText: A Cheyenne Warrior and U.S. Cavalry soldier hold a meeting next to a tipi

images.title: Cheyenne Dog Soldier Telling Stories
images.altText: A Cheyenne Dog Soldier tells stories inside his tipi

name: Weir Farm
description: Visit the home and studio of America's most beloved Impressionist, J. Alden Weir, and walk in the footsteps of generations of world-class artists. Set amidst more than 60 acres of painterly woods, fields, and waterways, you’ll soon see why Weir described his home as the "Great Good Place." Weir’s farm is a national legacy to American Impressionism, the creative spirit, and historic preservation.

images.title: Living Room of the Weir House
images.altText: The inside of a living room with two arm chairs and a table in between.

images.title: Plein Air Painting of Weir Studio
images.altText: A painting of a red building with the same building in the background.

name: Whiskeytown
description: Whiskeytown Lake’s crystal-clear water is perhaps the most recognized feature of the park. However, water-based recreation is only a part of what the 42,000-acre Whiskeytown National Recreation Area has to offer. Visit waterfalls, hike through rugged mountains, explore California Gold Rush history, and observe post-fire ecology in action. Your national park is calling...

images.title: A Beautiful Day on the Lake
images.altText: Crystal clear waters make for good paddling

images.title: A View from the Top
images.altText: Being on the Top of Shasta Bally

name: White Sands
description: Rising from the heart of the Tularosa Basin is one of the world's great natural wonders - the glistening white sands of New Mexico. Great wave-like dunes of gypsum sand have engulfed 275 square miles of desert, creating the world's largest gypsum dunefield. White Sands National Park preserves a major portion of this unique dunefield, along with the plants and animals that live here.

images.title: Aerial of Dunefield
images.altText: Aerial of white sand dunes.

images.title: Fall Colors
images.altText: Cottonwood trees with orange leaves.

name: Whitman Mission
description: One moment can change the fate of many nations. After thousands of years of habitation by the Cayuse Nation, life in the Columbia River Plateau begins to change rapidly with the influx of missionaries, newcomers from the Oregon Trail, and diseases. A single violent act of desperation to protect a community ignites a series of events that will reshape the United States forever.

images.title: Cayuse Woven Cornhusk Bag
images.altText: Cornhusk Flat Bag

images.title: Cultural Items
images.altText: An array of animal furs, beaded bags, and woven baskets

name: William Howard Taft
fullName: William Howard Taft National Historic Site
description: High atop one of Cincinnati's most prominent hilltops stands the two-story Greek Revival house where William Howard Taft was born and grew up. Hard work, a good education, and an interest in civic duty are attributes that made the Taft family outstanding leaders over the years. The environment that shaped Taft's character and philosophy is highlighted on a visit to the site.

images.title: Bookstore Area
images.altText: A lobby area with red and white square tiles and two people standing at a counter with a ranger.

images.title: Bookstore Area
images.altText: Several books and gift items arranged in rows on slotted walls

name: Wilson's Creek
description: Wilson's Creek was the first major Civil War battle fought west of the Mississippi River, and the site of the death of Nathaniel Lyon, the first Union general killed in action. The costly Southern victory on August 10, 1861, focused national attention on the war in Missouri. Wilson’s Creek NB commemorates and interprets the battle within the context of the war in the Trans-Mississippi West.

images.title: Edwards Cabin
images.altText: Women in reproduction historic dress sit and stand on porch of old cabin

images.title: Henry Rifle
images.altText: The receiver of an 1864 rifle shows decorative engraving with the original owner's name

name: Wind Cave
description: Wind Cave National Park protects two very different worlds - one deep within the earth, the other a sunlit world of many resources. Bison, elk, and other wildlife roam the rolling prairie grasslands and forested hillsides of one of America's oldest national parks. Below the remnant island of intact prairie sits Wind Cave, one of the longest and most complex caves in the world.

images.title: Bison cow and calf
images.altText: a bison cow and calf on the prairie

images.title: Boxwork
images.altText: criss-cross-patterned calcite fins of the cave feature boxwork

name: Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts
fullName: Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts
description: No matter what your age or taste in shows, you'll find something you like onstage at Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts. From May through September, multiple amphitheaters in the park present performances such as musicals, dance, opera, jazz, and popular and country music. A good time to explore the beauty and history of the park without the crowds is October - April.

images.title: Catherine Filene Shouse Bust
images.altText: Bust of Catherine Filene Shouse with building in back

images.title: Children's Theatre-in-the-Woods Performances
images.altText: Sold out show at Theatre-in-the-Woods

name: Women's Rights
description: Women’s Rights National Historical Park tells the story of the first Women’s Rights Convention, held in Seneca Falls, New York on July 19-20, 1848. It is a story of struggles for civil rights, human rights, and equality, global struggles that continue today. The efforts of women’s rights leaders, abolitionists, and other 19th century reformers remind us that all people must be accepted as equals.

images.title: Elizabeth Cady Stanton House
images.altText: The Elizabeth Cady Stanton House with a tree and National Park Service sign in the front yard

images.title: First Wave Statue
images.altText: A bronze statue group of people wearing 19th-century clothing.

name: World War I Memorial
description: A grateful nation honors the service, valor, courage and sacrifice of the 4.7 million American sons and daughters who served in the Great War.

images.title: General Pershing Statue
images.altText: General Pershing Statue

images.title: Peace Fountain
images.altText: Peace Fountain

name: World War II Memorial
description: Through stone architecture and bronze sculptures, the World War II Memorial recognizes the ways Americans served, honors those who fell, and recognizes the victory they achieved to restore freedom and end tyranny around the globe.

images.title: A Field of Stars
images.altText: Close up of Gold Stars in the Memorial

images.title: Aerial view of World War II Memorial
images.altText: Aerial view of stone columns around an oval-shaped pool at the World War II Memorial.

name: Wrangell - St Elias
fullName: Wrangell - St Elias National Park & Preserve
description: Wrangell-St. Elias is a vast national park that rises from the ocean all the way up to 18,008 ft. At 13.2 million acres, the park is the same size as Yellowstone National Park, Yosemite National Park, and Switzerland combined! Within this wild landscape, people continue to live off the land as they have done for centuries. This rugged, beautiful land is filled with opportunities for adventure.

images.title: Backpackers in Mentasta Mountains
images.altText: Two backpackers sitting in an alpine meadow with snowy mountains in the background

images.title: Chitina Ranger Station
images.altText: Chitina Ranger Station

name: Wright Brothers
description: Wind, sand, and a dream of flight brought Wilbur and Orville Wright to Kitty Hawk, North Carolina where, after four years of scientific experimentation, they achieved the first successful airplane flights on December 17, 1903. With courage and perseverance, these self-taught engineers relied on teamwork and application of the scientific process. What they achieved changed our world forever.

images.title: Busts and Moon
images.altText: Copper busts of the two brothers with the moon visible in the blue sky.

images.title: First Flight
images.altText: Orville takes to the air in the flyer for the first time as Wilbur assists.

name: Wupatki
description: Nestled between the Painted Desert and ponderosa highlands of northern Arizona Wupatki seems like an unlikely landscape for a thriving community. In the early 1100s during a time period of cooler temperatures and wetter seasons the ancestors of contemporary Pueblo communities created a bustling center of trade and culture. For Hopi people these sites represent the footprints of their ancestors.

images.title: Citadel Pueblo
images.altText: Side view of the Nalakihu and Citadel Pueblos

images.title: Dark Skies over the Desert
images.altText: stars and the Milky Way galaxy over a desert juniper tree

name: Yellowstone
description: On March 1, 1872, Yellowstone became the first national park for all to enjoy the unique hydrothermal wonders. Today, millions of people come here each year to camp, hike, and enjoy the majesty of the park.

images.title: Aurum Geyser
images.altText: A crowd of people standing along a wooden boardwalk watches a geyser erupt.

images.title: Beehive Geyser
images.altText: People on a wooden boardwalk watch a geyser erupt.

name: Yorktown Battlefield
fullName: Yorktown Battlefield Part of Colonial National Historical Park
description: Discover what it took for the United States to be independent as you explore the site of the last major battle of the Revolutionary War. Here at Yorktown, in the fall of 1781, General George Washington, with allied American and French forces, besieged General Charles Lord Cornwallis’s British army. On October 19, Cornwallis surrendered, effectively ending the war and ensuring independence.

images.title: Cannon at Sunset Yorktown Battlefield
images.altText: Cannon at sunset at Yorktown Battlefield

images.title: Lamb's Artillery Fire 18 pounder Cannon Yorktown Battlefield
images.altText: Lamb's Artillery Fire 18 pounder Cannon Yorktown Battlefield

name: Yosemite
description: Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, the persistence of life, and the tranquility of the High Sierra. First protected in 1864, Yosemite National Park is best known for its waterfalls, but within its nearly 1,200 square miles, you can find deep valleys, grand meadows, ancient giant sequoias, a vast wilderness area, and much more.

images.title: Cathedral Peak and Lake in Autumn
images.altText: A mountain reflecting in a lake.

images.title: El Capitan
images.altText: El Capitan and reflection in Merced River with some low clouds

name: Yucca House
description: Yucca House National Monument preserves a large unexcavated pueblo with a stunning setting in Montezuma Valley, nestled between Mesa Verde and Ute Mountain. Since Yucca House was protected as a national monument in 1919, it has remained largely untouched, offering intrepid visitors a sense of discovery and preserving the pueblo's beauty and integrity for future generations.

images.title: Ancestral Puebloan Wall at Yucca House
images.altText: Close up view of an ancient wall at Yucca House

images.title: View of Mesa Verde from Yucca House
images.altText: View of Mesa Verde landform

name: Yukon - Charley Rivers
description: Located in Interior Alaska, Yukon-Charley Rivers offers exploration in a largely untouched landscape. Whether you float the mighty Yukon River or paddle the Charley River's whitewater, your memories will last a lifetime. Geology, cultural history, gold rush remnants, wildlife, and vast scenery will be a part of your experience. But, the strongest element will be solitude. Your adventure awaits.

images.title: Aerial view of the Yukon River
images.altText: Aerial view of the Yukon River during fall colors

images.title: Calico Bluff and the Yukon River
images.altText: Calico Bluff rising above the Yukon River that also winds into the distance behind the bluff

name: Zion
description: Follow the paths where native people and pioneers walked. Gaze up at massive sandstone cliffs of cream, pink, and red that soar into a brilliant blue sky. Experience wilderness in a narrow slot canyon. Zion’s unique array of plants and animals will enchant you as you absorb the rich history of the past and enjoy the excitement of present day adventures.

images.title: Kolob Arch
images.altText: A red sandstone arch under a clear blue sky.

images.title: The Narrows
images.altText: Tall, red, sandstone walls enclose a narrow river.
